msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to Sophia Scott Lockhart, , April 7th 1837

div.p:
I wish it were the first of May
- and you my dear Mrs.
Lockhart know why - or
you may know why if you
consider for a moment-

The biography is most in=
teresting interesting - The biographer
of Leyden deserved him.
self to have such a biogra
pher biographer as he has - Crampton
our Surgeon General, of
whom you know nothing
but who is known to Mr.
Lockhart, as a man of abili
lities out os his own line &
of real feeling as I can at-
test, was the first person
in this country whose opinion

of the book I heard. He wrote
to me, delighted with it
"That is biography indeed!"
was what he said - and
I have a notion that in his
secret soul he compared
it with his friend Anacreon
Moores biographies - He is
very partial to Moore but
not so blind as not to see the
difference-

Mr. Lockhart makes
such admirable use of all
the letters - they so unfold
to the reader Sir Walter Scotts
mind from the earliest
times - Th life Here, Edgeworth is likely referring to Lockhart's publication of Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott and his own
admirable fragment throw
as much light as can be
given in confirmation of
the Biographers observations

Do you think that there is
any copy to be had of the
print of Bunbury's which
Burns saw at Prof.r Fergusons
of the dying soldier - I wish
you would have the goodness
to inquire at Colnaghis - I
should very much wish to
purchase a copy if it can be
had at any price.

My dear Mrs. Lockhart you
told me that if I missed any
of Sir Walter Scotts letters from
among those which I sent to
Mrr Lockhart & would tell you
you would search for them for me
- I miss one and but one; but
that one I should be very sorry
to lose - It is one which I sent
to Mr. Lockhart the first before
the portfolio full was sent
-It speaks of Sir Walters
having "lost only the trappings

of wealth"- and mentions the
"offers of assistance which had
"been made him from the
"highest persons in the land
"to the lowest"
You will oblige me very much
my dear Mrs Lockhart by plaguing
yourself and every body else
till you find it - as I hope you
will and then enclose it to me
under cover to L.t Col.l Yorke
Dublin Castle.

I am sure you know
what it is to have no power
of fixing attention in sorrow
upon any common place
reading & you may have felt
the charm of interesting writing
in taking ones snatching one
from oneself away in hours
of affliction - and you
know how much then we
have felt obliged to your
husband for this volume
